awd_abstract_narration:
This awards supports research in gravitational wave detector instrumentation, and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. Since its initial gravitational-wave discovery in 2015 the NSF's Advanced LIGO has observed numerous black hole and neutron star collisions, shedding new light on a broad set of questions in astrophysics, cosmology, fundamental physics, and nuclear physics. The observatories' sensitivity can be improved further by controlling thermal distortion effects when operating at high laser power, and by lowering the thermal noise in its test mass mirror coatings. This award funds research into better laser wave front distortion sensors and actuators, and supports collaborative research into finding better coating materials for terrestrial gravitational-wave detectors. Both research directions pursue the common goal of significantly expanding the observational reach of Advanced LIGO. The award provides students and postdocs access to a world-class observatory and prepares them for scientific leadership positions.

The award specifically provides funding for: (i.) The development mode-converter-based optical wave front sensors, capable of simultaneously sensing cavity alignment and mode-match for the Advanced LIGO detector. (ii.) The development of a phase camera, based on pixel-demodulation, to provide high-resolution RF beat maps of the laser field in the detector at a high frame rate. The camera is intended for use in interferometer commissioning and feedback control. (iii.) Exploring options for sensing and control of higher-order wave front aberrations. (iv.) Continued commissioning support in collaboration with LIGO Laboratory to improve the astrophysical sensitivity and bandwidth of Advanced LIGO in the upcoming O3 and O4 observing runs. (v.) Installation support for the construction and testing of a cryogenic nodal suspension for measuring mechanical loss of new coatings down to cryogenic temperatures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Albert Einstein predicted gravitational waves, ripples of warped spacetime that travel at the speed of light, over a century ago. In 2015, the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) opened a new window on the universe by directly observing gravitational waves from the merger of two black holes. Since then, Advanced LIGO has continued observing with greater sensitivity, yielding hundreds of observations of merging black holes and neutron stars and enabling electromagnetic follow-up observations.

The observatories' astrophysical reach can be improved further by controlling thermal distortion effects when operating at high laser power, and by lowering the thermal noise in its test mass mirror coatings. This requires better sensors and actuators for the laser phase front, and testing of new coating materials, both of which were goals of this award. Research sponsored through this award led to the following outcomes:

i) A suspended piezo-deformable and steerable mirror was developed in collaboration with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The mirror was installed in both Advanced LIGO detector?s optical output chain, controlling the laser beam from the interferometer. Its performance characteristics was published (Opt. Express 2022 Mar 28;30(7):10491-10501).

ii) The award funded a graduate student stationed at the LIGO Hanford Observatory, providing support for further improving the observatory?s astrophysical sensitivity for the O3 and O4 observing runs.

iii) A novel scheme to simultaneously sense cavity alignment and mode-match was developed, tested, and published (Phys. Rev. D 100, 102001). The scheme uses a pair of cylindrical mirrors and RF-demodulated quadrant photodiodes.

iv) The initial prototype of a novel camera, capable of observing the beat map of two laser phase fronts, was developed, and tested.  The camera can provide high-resolution RF beat maps of the laser field in the detector at a high video frame rate. It uses CMOS in-pixel demodulation technology originally developed for robotics applications. The camera is intended for interferometer diagnostic purposes.  

v) Finally, the award also provided support for a graduate student to construct and test a cryogenic apparatus for measuring mechanical loss of new optical coating materials down to 10 Kelvin.
